content: "http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/news/286875.php" and many other news sources today WASHINGTON — The recession is projected to wipe out annual cost-of-living increases for 50 million Social Security beneficiaries for the next three years, something that hasn't happened since automatic adjustments were adopted in 1975. The Congressional Budget Office says in its latest budget estimates that inflation will dip so low that Social Security recipients will not qualify for annual increases in 2010, or for two years after that. I bet congress gets their cost of living each year

content: I don't get the outrage here. Social Security benefits are legally tied to the cost of living. They are NOT being deprived of a cost of living increase - There is no rise in the cost of living. I'm a BIG supporter of SSI - And? If the Cost of living hasn't gone up, then it's unfair to give a raise in benefits. If we as a society CHOOSE to raise benefits, that's just fine with me. But that's a completely different topic. Dave

content: "http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/news/286875.php" and many other news sources today WASHINGTON — The recession is projected to wipe out annual cost-of-living increases for 50 million Social Security beneficiaries for the next three years, something that hasn't happened since automatic adjustments were adopted in 1975. The Congressional Budget Office says in its latest budget estimates that inflation will dip so low that Social Security recipients will not qualify for annual increases in 2010, or for two years after that. content: I don't get the outrage here. Social Security benefits are legally tied to the cost of living. They are NOT being deprived of a cost of living increase - There is no rise in the cost of living. I'm a BIG supporter of SSI - And? If the Cost of living hasn't gone up, then it's unfair to give a raise in benefits. If we as a society CHOOSE to raise benefits, that's just fine with me. But that's a completely different topic. Dave

content: "http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/news/286875.php" and many other news sources today WASHINGTON — The recession is projected to wipe out annual cost-of-living increases for 50 million Social Security beneficiaries for the next three years, something that hasn't happened since automatic adjustments were adopted in 1975. The Congressional Budget Office says in its latest budget estimates that inflation will dip so low that Social Security recipients will not qualify for annual increases in 2010, or for two years after that. I bet congress gets their cost of living each year

content: I don't get the outrage here. Social Security benefits are legally tied to the cost of living. If the Cost of living hasn't gone up, then it's unfair to give a raise in benefits. If we as a society CHOOSE to raise benefits, that's just fine with me. But that's a completely different topic. Dave

content: I don't get the outrage here. Social Security benefits are legally tied to the cost of living. They are NOT being deprived of a cost of living increase - There is no rise in the cost of living. I'm a BIG supporter of SSI - And? If the Cost of living hasn't gone up, then it's unfair to give a raise in benefits. If we as a society CHOOSE to raise benefits, that's just fine with me. But that's a completely different topic. Dave

content: "http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/news/286875.php" and many other news sources today WASHINGTON — The recession is projected to wipe out annual cost-of-living increases for 50 million Social Security beneficiaries for the next three years, something that hasn't happened since automatic adjustments were adopted in 1975. The Congressional Budget Office says in its latest budget estimates that inflation will dip so low that Social Security recipients will not qualify for annual increases in 2010, or for two years after that. I bet congress gets their cost of living each year

content: I don't get the outrage here. Social Security benefits are legally tied to the cost of living. Dave

content: "http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/news/286875.php" and many other news sources today WASHINGTON — The recession is projected to wipe out annual cost-of-living increases for 50 million Social Security beneficiaries for the next three years, something that hasn't happened since automatic adjustments were adopted in 1975. The Congressional Budget Office says in its latest budget estimates that inflation will dip so low that Social Security recipients will not qualify for annual increases in 2010, or for two years after that. I bet congress gets their cost of living each year

content: I don't get the outrage here. Social Security benefits are legally tied to the cost of living.
